headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: More Than 200 Countries Have Made The Pledge to Phase Out Fossil Fuels; Jobs Most Likely to be Impacted by AI. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Rapid advancement of AI platforms, such as ChatGPT has everyone from librarians to judges, to nurses, to criminal investigatorsasking how exposed is my job? PROF. ROBERT SEAMANS, MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZATIONS, NEW YORK UNIVERSITY: Lots of people are interested in understanding, what types of jobs are going to be affected by AI, what policy responses we might want to think about from a societal point of view.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is Professor and AI expert, Rob Seamans, and he co- authored a paper ranking, nearly 800 jobs in their exposure to artificial intelligence, particularly to AI language modeling.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: So I`m not in the top 20, however, I am number 22 on the list.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The methodology takes 52 human abilities used at various jobs as defined by the Department of Labor.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: There could be things like inductive and deductive reasoning, image recognition, language comprehension, and to ones that are much morephysical. So trunk strength, arm, hand, steadiness, something like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And maps those 52 human abilities to 10 areas where AI most excels.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: Things like image, generation, image recognition, language modeling, and things like that.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The more those AI skills and human abilities overlapped, the more a job was determined to be exposed to AI. To focus the study, theydid not consider the effects of robots and other automated machines in the research. And that skewed the rankings for some jobs that you might think would be more vulnerable to advances in technology.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: Workers in a manufacturing setting or maybe transportation and warehouse type settings, score very low in an exposure to AI, as opposed toexposure to other types of automation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The type of job is that the study found or most exposed to AI, white collar occupations, often with high education requirements andhigher pay.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: If you look at the top 20 occupations that are most exposed to advances in language modeling, 14 of those top 20 are professors. If youlook at the number one thing that a professor does, it`s prepare and deliver lectures. And we know that language modeling is really helpful when it comes to preparing content that you might later on, then deliver to a classroom.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: AI`s ability to recognize and generate language exposes a wide variety of white-collar professions, such as mental healthcounselors, writers, areas of the legal industry, even preachers.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: Now, praying, of course, large language models are not going to be very helpful with that. But in terms of creating the sermons that you mightdeliver, you would imagine that, you know, just like large language models could help a, a clergy person do that, same thing, with -- with a college professor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And the number one job that is most exposed, telemarketers.

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: Part of the reason why telemarketers are so exposed to advances in language modeling, have to do with probably the amount of, speaking thatthey do and the amount of, you know, listening and responding on the fly to the comments that they get from whoever they`re calling.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So how exactly might AI change our jobs in the future now?

utterances.speaker: SEAMANS
utterances.sentences: Just because an occupation is more exposed to advances in AI doesn`t mean that that job is that threat of being substituted, but it`snot that lots of jobs will disappear. I don`t think that will happen. However, I do think that many, many jobs will change. (END VIDEOTAPE)

A story from Scotland now, scientists believe the world`s carbon dioxide levels are at their highest level in more than 2 million years. These reports suggest removing CO2 from the atmosphere is a necessary part of keeping a healthy planet. Now, carbon capture and removal is still a relatively new and unproven field, but CNN`s Bill Weir traveled to Scotland to see if a startup there has one solution to remove carbon pollution already in the atmosphere. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) BILL WEIR, CNN CLIMATE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Over millennia, volcanic rocks have formed some of Scotland`s most spectacular sites, but now they could also provide a solution to pull carbon out of the sky and lock it underground. JIM MANN, FOUNDER & CEO UNDO: Rock weathering is a natural process, so CO2 in our atmosphere combines with water vapor in our atmosphere and they will react to form a weak carbonic acid, that reacts to certain types of rocks to remove CO2.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Scottish company Undo takes that natural process and dramatically accelerates it by grinding down volcanic rocks like basalt into a finepowder, the surface area increases so when the rock gets spread across agricultural land, there is more contact, rainfall, and CO2 and vastly more carbon is captured.

utterances.speaker: XINRAN LIU, HEAD OF SCIENCE AND RESEARCH, UNDO
utterances.sentences: UNIDENTIFIED MALEyour beans finely, you unlock those reactive surface areas and then you can mass, even create a very potent brew very quickly.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: When we`re putting the basalt down on agricultural land, we typically apply it at about 20 tons per hectare. And that`s across the whole farm sothousands and thousands of hectares now. And we`re spreading about 30,000 tons of silicate rock every month now. So that 30,000 tons will be in the somewhere region of 7,000 or 8,000 tons of CO2.

utterances.speaker: LIU
utterances.sentences: We have developed a detailed geochemical model to enable us to predict multiple decades into the future how much rock has been weathered. So fromcurrent finding, there is huge potential for enhanced rock weathering. We could contribute to 5-10 gigatons annually of carbon dioxide removal in the future. (END VIDEOTAPE)
